title: If no recordings happened before 1860, how did classical music save through the years? - Quora

response.answer_text: How do we know what Shakespeare’s plays were like, since movies weren’t invented until 1892? Answer: we have Shakespeare’s scripts. A script for a play doesn’t give us an exact representation. We don’t know if an actor picked up a prop at a particular time (unless there’s a stage direction for that specific action). We don’t know what his or her facial expression was. We don’t know if the original production starred an actor with a lisp, or a limp, or a red goatee. But we know what the words were, and we know what order they were spoken in. We know that because the scripts survive. It’s exactly the same thing with music. We don’t know exactly what bowing the violin used in the first performance of Bach’s partitas. We don’t know the exact tempo for the first performance of Beethoven’s fourth symphony, or whether the bassoon missed a note in the debut of one of Vivaldi’s concertos. But we know exactly what notes they played, and in what order. Because the scores survive. So we can recreate what we think happened. Scores, like play scripts, are NOT performances. They are instructions for performances. Like any written instructions, they are representations that were clearly understood at the time… but over time, the meaning can become a little fuzzy. If I say “my father”, you know what I mean, because you and I share the same language at the same moment in time. If I say “min faeder” you probably wouldn’t get the idea that I was talking about ‘my father’ - but if you rolled back the clock by 1000 years you’d get it, because that’s how it was written in middle English. In the context of a longer sentence or paragraph you might get the basic idea, but it’s not the same as the original communication. Same thing with music. The basic ideas HAVE changed. We’ve changed tunings - today we use equal temperament, Bach used well temperament, Godric of Finchale used mean temperament. The interpretation of notations have changed: grace notes today precede the main note, but in the 1700s they delayed the main note. Some musicologists work hard to try to recreate what, exactly, an original performance sounded like. Some ensembles use period instruments, which can be pretty different from their modern versions, to try to recreate sounds from the past. The farther back you go in time, the harder that is to do. But we do the best we can. And we work with what we’ve got. It’s entirely possible that Benjamin Franklin had a mole on the side of his nose, and he paid off the portrait artists to overlook it. We don’t know for sure. It’s entirely possible that our best recreations of a piece by Thomas Tallis is something he’d shake his head at and say ‘you just don’t get it’. We don’t know for sure. But like a Shakespeare play, we can still enjoy it. If you listen to a Bach piece played by a modern orchestra, and listen to the same piece played by a ‘historically informed performance’ group like St. Martin of the Fields, you will hear differences (if your ears are good enough). But don’t let that stand in the way of enjoying the beauty of the performance.

If no recordings happened before 1860, how did classical music save through the years? Before the invention of the phonograph people had devised a remarkable way to preserve their thoughts, ideas, and music. It was called pen and paper. Composers would use a pen to scribble the notes they wanted musicians to reproduce on special paper called “scores” which others could read. These “scores” could be taken to a print shop where they could be typeset and reproduced by the hundreds or thousands and then distributed so that musicians the world over could perform the works they had never before heard. Remarkable system that worked well for centuries. Even today musicians use these “scores” to reproduce music though most composers have now replace the pen and paper method with computer programs to transcribe their original works for distribution.
